chunks.original_text: ”若金水之数，及时相等，急以二分之火而合之。 是云：“火二与之俱。 ”金水火既已相合，则火受金炁，复得水制，结成还丹，乃能变化，而状若神矣。 下手临炉之工，莫此为要。 是以圣人年中取月而置金，月中测日而听潮，日中择时而应爻，时中定火而行符。 何谓行符古圣先贤以炼金丹为一大件事也，推度时节立攒簇法，以一年七十二候簇于一日，以三百六十爻攒于一月，以三十六符计一昼夜，分依十二时中。 是一时有六候，比之求丹，止用二候之火（一为久）； 一时有一爻，比之求丹，不要半爻之顷； 一时有三符，此之求丹，止用一符之速。 所谓单符单决者此也。 所以黄帝言《阴符》者此也。 故曰：“人知其神而神，不知不神之所以神”者，此也。 修丹仙子，于此一符之顷，蹙三千六百之正气，逆纳胎中。 当斯之时，夺天地之造化，窃日月之精华，地轴由心，天关在手，交龙虎两弦之炁，捣金水一体之真，龟蛇盘结于丹炉，乌免会行于黄道，黑白交映，刚柔迭兴，玉炉（一为户）储祥，紫华映日，荧惑守于西极，朱雀炎于空中，促水运金，催火入鼎，伏蒸以太阳之炁，结号黄舆之丹也。 夫初炼金水之时，堤防以岁月而计。 至于合丹之际，止用一符之工夫。 久则毁性而伤丹，一亏则伤寿年矣。 是云：“岁月将欲讫，毁性伤寿年。 ”修丹一事，本为延寿登真，若差一发，反伤寿矣。 故仙翁诲后学必要慎密明窗尘者，比丹之至微也。 “捣治”者，阴阳之交炼也； “持入”者，保持之而收入也； “赤色门”乃乾之户，丹从乾之户而归神室； “固塞”者，闭息也； “际会”者，九窍也。 皆要坚完而无所失。 “炎火张于下，昼夜声正勤”者，盖阳丹之初到，其中有信，乍得离中之火，昼夜周流一身，百节万神，悉皆听命，正宜勤勤内守，使声寂而意和，炁匀而脉住，丹始凝结。 “始文使可修”者，炼丹之始，用文火而修之。 其首尾则皆武火：首用武火以炼己，终用武火以温养。 故鼎器歌曰：“首尾武，中间文”是也。 “候视加谨慎”者，不可自取踈慢。 泥丸有云：“工夫不到不方圆”是也。 “审察调寒温”者，勿为人物所瞒。 紫阳翁曰：“调停火候托阴阳”是也。 周旋以十二节，终而复始，直待添汞抽铅，铅将尽，汞亦干，七魄已死魂亦变，是“炁索命将绝，体死亡魂魄”也。 景象至此，其色转为紫金赫赤之还丹也。 “粉提以一丸，刀圭最为神”者，其少如一提之粉，其小如一丸之药。 黍大曰“丸”，其轻如刀圭之匕，言至微也，而其神妙有不可述也。 此章备言下手之功，然细微玄旨，必师口传，孰能依文而成事哉先贤朱文公欲闻至道，不得师传，酷好此书，迨衰病中答侍郎袁公书曰：“《参同》之书，本不为明《易》，乃姑借此纳甲之法，以寓其行持进退之候。 ”文公该博如此，为无师指，想为纳甲之法。 恶知此书直欲明《周易》之道，故曰：《周易参同契》。 况丹道行持进退之候，并不用纳甲之法也。 又书云：近者道间不挟他书，遂得熟玩《参同》，粗能晓其文义。 盖向来虽屡看，率以无味弃去，今乃始识头绪，然未得其作料孔穴，夫玄言密旨，不可思议。 文公屡以无味弃去，盲师却要猜量。
chunks.translated_text:
If the quantities of gold and water are timely and equal, swiftly apply the fire of two parts to unite them. This is what is meant by, *"The fire of two accompanies them."*

Once gold, water, and fire have merged, the fire receives the gold’s *qi*, and is further restrained by the water, coalescing into the Reverted Elixir. Thus transformed, its state becomes divine.

No step in the furnace-work is more crucial than this. Therefore, the sage selects the month from the year to place the gold, measures the day within the month to heed the tide, chooses the hour within the day to align with the hexagram, and fixes the fire within the hour to enact the talisman.

What is meant by "enacting the talisman"? The ancient sages and worthies regarded the refinement of the Golden Elixir as a matter of utmost importance. They calculated the seasons and established the method of *cuan cu* (gathering and clustering), condensing the seventy-two seasonal nodes of a year into a single day, the three hundred sixty hexagrams of a year into a single month, and the thirty-six talismans into one day and night, distributing them across the twelve hours.

Each hour contains six nodes—yet in the quest for the Elixir, only the fire of two nodes is employed (one for prolonged duration). Each hour holds one hexagram—yet in the quest for the Elixir, not even half a hexagram’s moment is needed. Each hour comprises three talismans—yet in the quest for the Elixir, only the swiftness of one talisman is used. This is what is meant by *single talisman, single decision*. Thus did the Yellow Emperor speak of the *Yin Fu Jing*. Hence it is said: *"People know the divine as divine, yet do not know the non-divine that makes the divine divine."* This is the principle.

At the moment of this single talisman, the immortal adept of the Elixir compresses the three thousand six hundred breaths of primordial *qi*, drawing them in reverse into the womb. In this instant, they seize the creative power of Heaven and Earth, steal the essence of the sun and moon, hold the Earth’s axis in their heart and the Heaven’s gate in their hands. They blend the *qi* of the dragon and tiger’s two strings, pound the true essence of gold and water into one, coil the tortoise and snake within the Elixir furnace, and unite the crow and hare upon the Yellow Path. Black and white intermingle, hardness and softness alternate in rise, the jade crucible (or "door") stores auspiciousness, and purple radiance reflects the sun. Mars guards the western pole, the Vermilion Bird flames in the void. They hasten the water to move the gold, urge the fire into the tripod, subdue and steam with the *qi* of the Great Yang, and coagulate the Elixir named the Yellow Chariot.

When first refining gold and water, one must guard against reckoning in years and months. Yet at the moment of uniting the Elixir, only the work of a single talisman is required. Prolonged effort damages one’s nature and harms the Elixir; a single misstep shortens one’s lifespan. This is what is meant by, *"As the years and months draw to a close, nature is damaged and lifespan harmed."*

The practice of refining the Elixir is fundamentally for prolonging life and ascending to immortality. Yet if one errs by a hair’s breadth, it instead shortens life. Thus the Immortal Elder admonishes later learners: the utmost care must be taken, for the dust on a bright window is like the subtlety of the Elixir.

*"Pounding and refining"* refers to the intermingling and tempering of yin and yang. *"Holding and entering"* means preserving and gathering it in. The *"Crimson Gate"* is the portal of *qian* (Heaven); the Elixir returns through *qian*’s gate to the chamber of spirit. *"Sealing firmly"* means closing the breath. *"Meeting at the juncture"* refers to the nine orifices. All must be secure and complete, without any loss.

*"Flames blaze below, day and night the sound is diligent"*—for when the Yang Elixir first arrives, it bears a sign. Suddenly receiving the fire within *li* (Fire), it circulates day and night throughout the body. Every joint and myriad spirits obey its command. One must diligently guard within, ensuring the sound is still and the intent harmonious, the *qi* even and the pulse stilled, so the Elixir may begin to congeal.

*"At first, refine with civil fire"*—at the beginning of Elixir refinement, use civil fire. Yet from start to finish, martial fire is employed: first to refine the self, and finally to warm and nurture. Thus the *Tripod Song* says: *"Martial at start and end, civil in the middle."*

*"Observe and act with utmost care"*—one must not grow careless. The *Mud Pill Palace* states: *"Without sufficient effort, the work will not be perfected."*

*"Examine and adjust cold and warmth"*—do not be deceived by external things. Master Purple Yang said: *"Adjust the fire’s timing by entrusting it to yin and yang."*

Circling through the twelve joints, beginning anew after completion, one continues until the mercury is added and the lead withdrawn. When the lead is nearly exhausted and the mercury also dries, the seven *po* are dead and the *hun* transformed—this is *"the qi is spent, life nears its end, the body dies, and the hun and po depart."*

At this stage, the Elixir’s color shifts to the crimson-gold radiance of the Reverted Elixir.

*"Powdered to a single grain, the knife’s tip is most divine"*—as fine as a pinch of powder, as small as a single pill. A grain of millet is called a *"pill,"* and its lightness is like the tip of a knife’s blade, speaking to its subtlety. Yet its divine marvels are beyond description.

This chapter exhaustively describes the work of beginning the practice. Yet its profound and abstruse principles must be transmitted orally by a master—who could accomplish this by relying solely on the text?

Master Zhu Xi of the former worthies, desiring to hear the supreme Dao but lacking a teacher’s transmission, was deeply fond of this book. In his declining years, in a letter to Minister Yuan, he wrote: *"The *Cantong Qi* was not originally written to elucidate the *Book of Changes*. Rather, it merely borrowed the method of *na jia* (hexagram arrangement) to embed its practices of advancement and retreat."*

Master Zhu was so broadly learned, yet without a teacher’s guidance, he could only conceive of it as the method of *na jia*. How would he know this book truly aims to elucidate the Dao of the *Zhou Changes*? Hence its title: *The Kinship of the Three in Accord with the Zhou Changes*. Moreover, the practices of advancement and retreat in the Dao of the Elixir do not employ the *na jia* method at all.

Elsewhere, he wrote: *"Recently, while traveling, I carried no other books and thus became thoroughly familiar with the *Cantong Qi*, roughly grasping its literary meaning. Though I had read it many times before, I always set it aside as tasteless. Only now have I begun to discern its thread. Yet I still lack its ingredients, holes, and cavities—the profound words and secret principles are beyond imagination."*

Master Zhu repeatedly cast it aside as tasteless, while blind teachers insist on guessing.

chunks.original_text: 又云：异时每欲学之，不得其传，无下手处。 则圣贤非师，慧同孔孟，奚自会邪今人自满自足，妄猜妄为，若视前贤，其罪多矣。 使熹得师指授，大明圣人易道，必不固执为卜筮之书也。 水火情性章第十五 推演五行数，较约而不繁。 举水以激火，奄然灭光明。 日月相薄蚀，常在朔望间。 水盛坎侵阳，火衰离昼昏。 阴阳相饮食，交感道自然。 名者以定情，字者以性言。 金来归性初，乃得称还丹。 吾不敢虚说，仿效圣人文。 古记题龙虎，黄帝美金华。 淮南炼秋石，玉阳加黄芽。 贤者能持行，不肖毋与俱。 古今道由一，对谈吐所谋。 学者加勉力，留念深思惟。 至要言甚露，昭昭不我欺。 注云：“五行数”者，金、木、水、火、土，推而为三五一之数。 如炼金丹，则以铅、汞、银、砂、土为五行，而配合阴阳。 故水能灭火者，谓阴能消阳。 日月薄蚀，必在朔望，阴阳二者盛衰相侵。 若阴阳和，两相饮食，则自然有交感之道矣。 金与水同名曰“情”，木与火同字曰“性”。 情居西北，性主东南； 东南曰“我”，西北曰“彼”。 金水之情，自然外来，而克木火，木火之性，乃内还而结金丹。 是之谓“金来归性初，乃得称还丹”，是此二句为《参同》之骨髓也。 “吾不敢虚说，仿效圣人文”者，仙翁得圣人之的旨，复获古文《龙虎经》，依法修炼而丹成，乃撰此书，以训于后。 因历叙黄帝之丹成曰“金华”，淮南之丹成曰“秋石”，玉阳丹成曰“黄芽”。 丹成冲举，各立一名，无非是此还丹也，无非是先天一气也，无非同类之物也。 后人闻“金华”即猜为五金； 闻“黄芽”即猜为八石； 闻“秋石”即猜为便溺。 岂知古圣先贤方便立名，所炼之丹，奚出阴阳之外而别有路耶此道惟圣人为能勤行，自古迄今，一道而已。 三教大圣，必须同类，方可施功，故云：“古今道犹一，对谈吐所谋”，除此一途，更无他术。 后之来者勉力深思，求师指示，则知是书昭昭尽露，不我欺矣。 上阳子曰：“《参同契》三篇，体用不杂，功妙非常。 参者，参天地造化之体； 同者，资同类生成之用； 契者，合造化生成之功。 上篇叙炼丹之本末，中篇列细微之密旨，下篇补遗脱之法象。 ”上篇与《龙虎上经》表里义合，世疑《龙虎经》必后人祖《参同契》上篇述以为经，亦必有上、中、下三经也。 若无中下经，则何以谓之上经圣人之心，众人岂识盖上经者，首经之义，此固非凡可测。 又况书中有“古记题龙虎”之句，以是明之，则上古之文何疑故云金碧古文。 真人彭晓序谓：“仙翁不知师授谁氏，得古文《龙虎经》，尽获妙旨，乃约《周易》撰《参同契》三篇。 ”又云：“未尽纤微，复作补塞遗脱一篇，继演丹经之玄奥。 盖仙翁初授真人阴长生之旨，后复师徐从事，由是备悉玄微，仙传载详。 ”真一又云：“书成密授青州徐从事，徐乃隐名而注之。 ”是则源流，真实奚辩!此书之注何啻百余，惟彭晓、王道为优，如晓得师授受，观其明镜图，《参同》序亦已详明，而所注此书，尚自碎杂。 故有畎浍殊流，妍媸互起之语。 王道所释，尤为旷涸。 今详《龙虎经》。 言虽高古，不若《参同契》之明且诀也。 其语幽玄隐妙，非得圣师叮咛下手之的，孰敢拟议如“金来归性初，乃得称还丹”之下，便接“吾不敢虚说，仿效圣人文”则知古圣大贤，非有所师，宁敢虚说也!非师岂成是书也，非师怎合造化也!留此书于世者，圣心道眼也，天梯河筏也，修行人仰赖也。

Moreover, he stated: *"In the past, whenever I wished to study it, I could find no transmission, no place to begin."* If even sages and worthies, whose wisdom equals that of Confucius and Mencius, require a teacher, how could they have grasped it on their own? Yet today’s people, self-satisfied and complacent, recklessly guess and act—compared to the former worthies, their transgressions are many indeed. Had I, Xi, received a teacher’s guidance, I would have fully illuminated the sages’ Way of the *Changes* and surely not clung to it as a mere book of divination.

**Chapter Fifteen: The Nature of Water and Fire**
Expounding the numbers of the Five Phases,
Concise yet not convoluted.
Water is raised to provoke fire,
Suddenly extinguishing its radiance.
Sun and moon mutually eclipse,
Ever at the new and full moons.
When water waxes, *kan* encroaches on yang;
When fire wanes, *li* dims the day.
Yin and yang consume each other,
Their interaction the natural Dao.
Names define their essence,
Characters speak of their nature.
When metal returns to the origin of nature,
Only then is it called the Reverted Elixir.
I dare not speak idly,
But emulate the sages’ writings.
Ancient records title it *Dragon and Tiger*;
The Yellow Emperor praised *Golden Flower*.
Huainan refined *Autumn Stone*,
Yuyang added *Yellow Sprout*.
The worthy can uphold and practice it;
The unworthy must not partake.
The Dao of past and present is one,
Spoken in dialogue, disclosed in counsel.
Scholars, exert yourselves,
Reflect deeply and ponder.
The essential words are utterly plain,
Luminous and never deceiving.

The annotation states: *"The numbers of the Five Phases"* refer to metal, wood, water, fire, and earth, extended into the numbers three, five, and one. In the refinement of the Golden Elixir, lead, mercury, silver, cinnabar, and earth serve as the Five Phases, paired and harmonized with yin and yang. Thus, *"water extinguishes fire"* means yin dissolves yang. *"Sun and moon mutually eclipse"* necessarily at the new and full moons, where yin and yang wax and wane, encroaching upon each other. If yin and yang harmonize, mutually consuming, then the natural Dao of interaction arises. Metal and water share the name *"essence"*; wood and fire share the character *"nature."* Essence resides in the northwest, nature governs the southeast; the southeast is called *"self,"* the northwest *"other."* The essence of metal and water naturally comes from without, overcoming wood and fire, while the nature of wood and fire inwardly returns to congeal the Golden Elixir. This is what is meant by *"When metal returns to the origin of nature, only then is it called the Reverted Elixir"*—these two lines are the marrow of the *Cantong Qi*.

*"I dare not speak idly, but emulate the sages’ writings"*—the Immortal Elder grasped the sages’ true intent and, having obtained the ancient text *Dragon and Tiger Classic*, refined the Elixir according to its method. Upon its completion, he composed this book to instruct later generations. He recounted the Yellow Emperor’s Elixir, named *"Golden Flower,"* Huainan’s Elixir, named *"Autumn Stone,"* and Yuyang’s Elixir, named *"Yellow Sprout."* Each Elixir, upon ascension, bore a distinct name, yet all were this Reverted Elixir, all were the primordial qi, all were of the same kind. Later people, hearing *"Golden Flower,"* guessed it to be the five metals; hearing *"Yellow Sprout,"* guessed it to be the eight minerals; hearing *"Autumn Stone,"* guessed it to be urine sediment. How could they know that the ancient sages and worthies, in their expedient naming, refined an Elixir that transcends yin and yang, following no other path? This Dao can only be diligently practiced by sages. From antiquity to the present, it has been one and the same. The great sages of the Three Teachings must be of the same kind to apply their efforts, hence: *"The Dao of past and present is one, spoken in dialogue, disclosed in counsel."* Apart from this single path, there is no other method. Those who come after, exert yourselves and reflect deeply; seek a teacher’s guidance, and you will know that this book’s clarity leaves nothing concealed, never deceiving us.

Master Shangyang said: *"The three chapters of the *Cantong Qi* are unadulterated in substance and function, their efficacy extraordinary. 'To *participate*' is to partake in the creative workings of heaven and earth; 'to *unite*' is to rely on the generative function of like kind; 'to *accord*' is to harmonize with the creative and generative power of the cosmos. The first chapter recounts the origin and completion of Elixir refinement; the middle chapter enumerates its subtle and profound principles; the final chapter supplements omissions and restores symbolic correspondences."* The first chapter aligns in meaning with the *Dragon and Tiger Upper Classic*, and the world suspects that the *Dragon and Tiger Classic* must have been derived from the first chapter of the *Cantong Qi*, which was originally intended as a classic. It must have had upper, middle, and lower chapters. Without the middle and lower chapters, how could it be called the *Upper Classic*? The sages’ intent—how could the common people fathom it? The *Upper Classic* embodies the meaning of the *First Classic*, a profundity beyond mortal reckoning. Moreover, the book contains the line *"ancient records title it Dragon and Tiger,"* which clarifies that the ancient text is beyond doubt—hence the reference to *"ancient script in gold and jade."*

Master Peng Xiao’s preface states: *"The Immortal Elder’s teacher remains unknown, but he obtained the ancient *Dragon and Tiger Classic*, fully grasping its profound principles. He then condensed the *Zhou Changes* to compose the three chapters of the *Cantong Qi*."* It further states: *"Not all subtleties were exhausted, so he wrote an additional chapter to fill gaps and supplement omissions, further expounding the mysteries of the Elixir Classic."* The Immortal Elder first received the teachings of the Realized One Yin Changsheng, then later studied under Attendant Xu, thereby fully comprehending the profound subtleties. The immortal traditions record this in detail.

Master Zhenyi also said: *"Upon completion, the book was secretly transmitted to Attendant Xu of Qingzhou, who concealed his name and annotated it."* Thus, the lineage is genuine—what dispute could there be? The commentaries on this book number over a hundred, but only those by Peng Xiao and Wang Dao are superior. Peng Xiao, having received transmission, observed the *Bright Mirror Diagram*, and his preface to the *Cantong Qi* is already detailed. Yet his commentary on the book remains fragmented and disordered, giving rise to the saying: *"Rivulets diverge, beauty and ugliness arise together."* Wang Dao’s explanations are even more desolate and barren.

Now, examining the *Dragon and Tiger Classic*—though its language is archaic and lofty, it does not match the *Cantong Qi* in clarity and decisiveness. Its words are abstruse and recondite; without a sage-teacher’s precise instruction on where to begin, who would dare conjecture? After the lines *"When metal returns to the origin of nature, only then is it called the Reverted Elixir,"* it immediately follows with *"I dare not speak idly, but emulate the sages’ writings."* From this, we know that the ancient sages and great worthies, without a teacher, would never have dared to speak idly! Without a teacher, how could this book have been composed? Without a teacher, how could they have aligned with the workings of creation? The one who left this book for the world possessed the sagely mind and the Dao-eye, a ladder to heaven and a raft across the river—those who cultivate the Dao depend upon it.

chunks.original_text: 世无此书，则皆趋入旁门耶径，使盲师俗子架空捏怪，相牵引动挽入地狱尔。 世非此书，则天地之间无修行之旨，无圣人之道也。 已欲成天下之亹亹者，其何以哉留念深思，惟仙翁其天矣。 大凡注书，注者，释也。 其书隐奥难见，解释以晓后来。 故必得一书之本意，必超前人之心地，明彻洞达，所注过于所作之书，方可注释。 否则，彼处又不详，此处又不解，反误却后人。 智慧低隘了方来耳目，莫谓后之来者不如今也。 倘天生圣哲，欲正救之，则被其浊乱而不得分其清，归其正矣。 其他经书尚可，如此书者，伯阳面拜阴、徐二真人，至道之正，其高制雄辞，幽藏奥旨，一字不苟，况以金丹之法之妙，鼎器之穴之用，何啻百件伯阳止以“金来归性初”一语皆尽!宋儒未达，不肯明《周易》之道，总看为卜筮之书，暗藏却羲文周孔神圣之心，黯却乾坤顺逆造化之道，枉屈伯阳踵制元言之谛。 今若不晓露些孔窍，则四圣之心，万世莫伸； 大易之道，万世莫明。
chunks.translated_text:
Were this book not in the world, all would rush into heterodox paths and deviant byways, allowing blind masters and vulgar charlatans to fabricate absurdities, dragging one another into hell. Without this book, the realm between heaven and earth would lack the essence of cultivation and the Dao of the sages. How then could one aspire to guide the world’s ceaseless striving? Ponder deeply and reflect—only the immortal patriarchs possess such heavenly insight.

In general, to annotate a text is to elucidate it. When a book’s meaning is recondite and obscure, explication serves to enlighten later generations. Thus, one must grasp the book’s fundamental intent, surpass the mental plane of predecessors, and achieve luminous clarity—only then may one’s annotations surpass the original work. Otherwise, ambiguities here and obscurities there will mislead posterity. Those of narrow wisdom and limited vision may assume later scholars cannot rival the ancients. Yet if a sage or wise one arises to rectify and salvage the truth, their efforts may be muddled by confusion, unable to distinguish purity from corruption or restore the proper path.

Other scriptures may tolerate such flaws, but this book—before which Boyang knelt in homage to the two Perfected Ones, Yin and Xu—embodies the orthodoxy of the supreme Dao. Its lofty diction and profound mysteries are rendered with meticulous precision; how much more so the subtleties of the Golden Elixir’s method, the crucible’s chamber and its function? Boyang encapsulated all with the single phrase: *"When metal returns to the origin of nature."* The Song Confucians, failing to comprehend, refused to acknowledge the *Zhouyi* as a work of the Dao, dismissing it as a mere divination manual. Thus, they obscured the sacred intent of Fuxi, King Wen, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius, and distorted the creative and transformative principles of Qian and Kun. They wrongly constrained Boyang’s profound and primal words.

If we do not now reveal some of its key apertures, the hearts of the Four Sages will remain unvindicated for ten thousand generations, and the Way of the *Great Change* will remain forever obscure.

Without a teacher, how could this book have been composed? Without a teacher, how could they have aligned with the workings of creation? The one who left this book for the world possessed the sagely mind and the Dao-eye, a ladder to heaven and a raft across the river—those who cultivate the Dao depend upon it.

How could one not know that the most essential words are utterly manifest, their earnestness expressed in the phrase: *"Luminous and clear—they do not deceive me"*?

**Chapter Sixteen: The Essence and Qi of Yin and Yang**

Qian’s firmness and Kun’s softness,
paired and interwoven.
Yang bestows, Yin receives—
male and female each in need of the other.
Through their union, creation unfolds,
and essence and qi expand.
Kan and Li crown the head,
their radiance streaming forth.
Mysterious and unfathomable,
beyond all depiction.

The sage measures and orders,
aligning the primal foundations.
These four—chaotic and indistinct—
plunge directly into emptiness.
The sixty hexagrams cycle,
spread wide as a chariot’s canopy.
Dragon and horse are harnessed,
the enlightened ruler steers the times.
Harmony follows in accord,
the path smooth, without deviation.
Deviant ways are perilous and obstructed,
toppling nations into ruin.

**Annotation:** The preceding fourteen chapters have already clarified the stages of elixir refinement from beginning to end. This section revisits the subtleties, chapter by chapter, outlining the combined application of the Nine-Return Great Elixir. Later scholars must delve deeply to attain thorough understanding; they cannot waver or compromise, for even the slightest error will prevent the elixir’s formation. Master Shangyang divided this middle section into fifteen chapters, enumerating fifteen matters. This chapter alone elucidates the four aspects of yin, yang, essence, and qi.

What are Qian’s firmness and Kun’s softness? Confucius’s *Wings* states: *"Qian is the yang thing; Kun is the yin thing. Yin and yang unite their powers, and firmness and softness take form, embodying the mechanism of Heaven and Earth, penetrating the virtue of the numinous."* Thus, Qian’s power is firm, strong, centered, and upright—pure and unadulterated essence. Kun’s power is yielding, compliant, beneficial, and steadfast. The noble person’s conduct follows this; the union of Qian and Kun is the Dao of the Golden Elixir. Only the noble person can act accordingly; the petty person does otherwise.

Formerly, Confucius said: *"I have never seen a truly firm person."* Someone replied: *"Shen Cheng is firm."* The Master said: *"Cheng is full of desire—how can he be firm?"* The meaning of firmness is vast indeed! Petty persons may force themselves to be firm and strong for a time, but how can they remain centered and upright? Without centering and uprightness, how can their essence be pure? Firmness is the nature of Qian—active and direct, thus easy to know. Softness is the nature of Kun—active and yielding, thus easy to follow. What is easy to know engenders intimacy; what is easy to follow brings achievement. Intimacy leads to accomplishment, allowing greatness and endurance—this is the virtue and work of sages and worthies.

To establish oneself between firmness and softness—is this not the Dao of the Golden Elixir? Thus, Qian’s yang power governs bestowal, while Kun’s yin power specializes in containment. *"Male and female each in need of the other"* relies on essence and qi; the expansion of essence and qi requires male and female. The *Wings* says: *"Essence and qi become things; wandering spirits become transformations."* *"Becoming things"* refers to the generative process—giving rise to humans and all beings. *"Becoming transformations"* refers to the reversal of this process—attaining Buddhahood or immortality.

What is meant by *"Kan and Li crown the head"*? When Qian’s firmness interacts with Kun, Qian’s center becomes hollow, forming Li. When Kun’s softness receives Qian, Kun’s interior becomes solid, forming Kan. Thus, Kan and Li succeed Qian and Kun, crowning the head of yin and yang while attaining the correctness of firmness and softness. The sun’s light within Li and the moon’s brilliance within Kan shine downward, their profound mystery too obscure to fathom or depict.

chunks.original_text: 故九龄往而国忠进，安史始萌； 秦桧用而岳飞亡，燕云莫复。 正人力为国者，惟恐国之权不在君； 小人只为身者，惟恐国之柄不属己。 君子小人，无世不有。 君子当和而容小人，小人宜随而从君子，则国无倾危，而天下治矣。 比之修炼，以和为先，和则事皆随心而应。 《翼》曰：“和兑之吉，行未疑也。 ”事既和矣（一为已），必正其心，必诚其意，必防其虑，则无险阻，而不倾丧其丹。 毫发之差，可不慎乎后二十八章，重明四者尤详。 君子居室章第十七 君子居其室，出其言善，则千里之外应之。 谓万乘之主，处九重之室，发号出令，顺阴阳节。 藏器俟时，勿违卦月。 屯以子申，蒙用寅戍。 余六十卦，各自有日。 聊陈两象，未能究悉。 立义设刑，当仁施德，逆之者凶，顺之者吉。 按历法令，至诚专密。 谨候日辰，审查消息。 纤芥不正，悔吝为贼。 二至改度，乖错委曲。 隆冬大暑，盛夏霜雪。 二分纵横，不应漏刻。 水旱相伐，风雨不节，蝗虫涌沸，群异旁出。 天见其怪，山崩地裂。 孝子用心，感动皇极。 近出己口，远流殊域。 或以招祸，或以至福，或兴太平，或造兵革。 四者之来，由乎胸臆。 动静有常，奉其绳墨。 四时顺宜，与炁相得。 刚柔断矣，不相涉入。 五行守界，不妄盈缩。 易行周流，屈伸反覆。 注云：此章最为入室之初，防闲细密，炼丹之难，等等如是。 圣人特以君子喻之，故《翼》之“系辞”曰：“君子居其室，出其言善，则千里之外应之。 ”况其迩者乎又曰：“言行，君子之枢机，枢机之发，荣辱之主也。 言行，君子之所以动天地也。 ”又曰：“拟之而后言，议之而后动，拟议以成其变化。 ”上阳子曰：“道本无言，非言何由显道谓无言者，有德之士，言不可以不慎也。 况行道修丹之士乎老子曰：‘知者不言，言者不知。 ’故逞乾慧无所知者，其发言论辩，无非求知也。 真师则能察其诳妄，浅器必不轻论。 ”紫阳公云：“虽鼎镬在前，刀锯加颈，亦不敢言。 ”若是真实行道之器，恶可不言且入室采药，切忌轻言。 果若不言，则何以得其药之真泥丸有云：“言语不通其眷属，工夫不到不方圆。 ”仙翁乃引仙圣之言，而又伸之，此谓“万乘之主，处九重之室，发号出令，顺阴阳节。 ”言求丹必顺阴阳节候，即一阳来复之际。 “藏器待时，勿违卦月”，言采药必待月现震生，即三日出庚之时。 “屯以子申”，乃生水旺之处； “蒙用寅戌”，乃火生库之位。 其六十卦，各有其日。 聊陈二卦，即屯卦也。 “未能究悉”者，仙翁自谓未能尽究详悉。 盖元奥要口授，故经云：“非世上之常辞。 ”上圣已成真人，通玄究微，能悉其意。 此言“未能究悉”者，世无上圣之资，岂能行此道而成真人哉!“立义设刑”，所以防其欺诈； “当仁施德”，所以诱其欢心。 “逆之者凶，顺之者吉”，按依法度，历明号令，用须至诚，行宜专密也。 “谨候日辰”者，一年止在一月，一月止有一日，一日止在一时，一时止用一符。 “审察消息”者，必要知其兑金所生之水，清浊分数，倘毫厘有差，“纤芥不正”，必招责吝，贼害丹炉。 如此乖错则阴阳差忒，二至改度，隆冬反为大暑，盛夏而有严霜。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, when the ninefold lifespan departed and Guozhong advanced, the An-Shi rebellion began to sprout; when Qin Hui rose and Yue Fei perished, the Yan-Yun lands were never reclaimed. Those of upright strength who serve the state fear only that state power may not rest with the ruler; petty men who serve only themselves fear only that state authority may not belong to them. The noble and the base exist in every age. The noble should harmonize with and tolerate the base, while the base ought to follow and submit to the noble—thus the state will know no peril, and all under heaven will be well-governed.

In cultivation and refinement, harmony comes first. When harmony prevails, all affairs follow the heart’s intent and respond accordingly. The *Wings* states: *"The auspiciousness of harmonious Dui means action encounters no doubt."* Once affairs are harmonized (or once the self is aligned), one must rectify the heart, sincerify the intent, and guard against wayward thoughts—then no obstacles will arise, nor will the elixir be lost. Even the slightest deviation demands the utmost caution.

The latter twenty-eight chapters re-emphasize these four principles in greater detail.

**Chapter Seventeen: The Noble One Dwelling in His Chamber**

When the noble one dwells in his chamber and utters good words, they resonate even a thousand *li* away. This refers to the ruler of ten thousand chariots, abiding within the ninefold palace, issuing decrees and commands in accord with the rhythms of yin and yang. Concealing his vessel, he awaits the proper time, never transgressing the hexagram’s month. *Zhun* employs the *zi* and *shen* [hours], *Meng* employs the *yin* and *xu* [hours]. The remaining sixty hexagrams each have their own appointed days. Here, two images are briefly presented, though their full intricacies remain unexplored.

Establishing righteousness and instituting punishments serve to prevent deceit; enacting benevolence and bestowing virtue serve to cultivate goodwill. Those who defy them meet misfortune; those who comply attain fortune. Adhering to the calendar and decrees, one must act with utmost sincerity and focused precision. Diligently observe the celestial stems and branches, scrutinizing the waxing and waning of yin and yang. Even the slightest irregularity invites regret and harm.

At the solstices, the celestial degrees shift; errors and distortions arise. Midwinter brings scorching heat, midsummer yields frost and snow. At the equinoxes, the cardinal directions misalign, failing to correspond even by a moment’s measure. Drought and flood contend, wind and rain fall out of season; locusts surge like boiling water, and manifold anomalies emerge. Heaven displays its omens—mountains collapse, the earth splits. The filial son’s devotion moves the imperial pole.

Words uttered near at hand flow afar to distant lands. They may summon disaster or bring fortune, usher in great peace or incite warfare. These four outcomes arise from the heart’s depths. Movement and stillness follow constant principles, adhering to their guiding lines. The four seasons proceed in due order, harmonizing with the *qi*. Firmness and softness are decisively distinguished, never encroaching upon one another. The Five Phases guard their boundaries, neither recklessly expanding nor contracting. The *Yi* circulates in ceaseless flow, bending and stretching, reversing and returning.

The commentary notes: This chapter marks the initial entry into the chamber, where vigilance and meticulous care are paramount—the difficulty of elixir refinement is precisely thus. The sage employs the analogy of the noble one, hence the *Wings*’ *"Appended Judgments"* states: *"When the noble one dwells in his chamber and utters good words, they resonate even a thousand *li* away. How much more so for those near at hand!"* It further says: *"Words and deeds are the noble one’s pivot and trigger; their release determines honor or disgrace. Words and deeds are how the noble one moves heaven and earth."* And again: *"Deliberate before speaking, consult before acting—deliberation and consultation bring about their transformations."*

Master Shangyang said: *"The Dao is fundamentally wordless; without words, how could the Dao be revealed?"* By *"wordless,"* he refers to those of virtue, whose words cannot be spoken carelessly. How much more so for those who practice the Dao and refine the elixir! Laozi said: *"Those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know."* Thus, those who flaunt their *qian*-wisdom without true understanding—when they expound and debate, they seek only to be known. A true master can discern their deceit and falsehood; the shallow and unworthy must not lightly discuss such matters.

Master Ziyang said: *"Even if a cauldron and axe stood before me, or a blade pressed against my neck, I would not dare speak."* Such is the vessel of one who truly practices the Dao—how could they not speak? Yet when entering the chamber to gather the medicine, one must avoid careless words. If one truly refrains from speaking, how can the medicine’s authenticity be discerned?

The *Niwan* states: *"If words fail to connect with one’s kin, the work will not achieve its proper form."* The immortal elder thus cites the words of sages and immortals, expanding upon them: *"The ruler of ten thousand chariots, abiding within the ninefold palace, issues decrees and commands in accord with the rhythms of yin and yang."* This means that seeking the elixir must follow the rhythms of yin and yang, precisely at the moment when solitary yang returns.

*"Concealing the vessel and awaiting the time, never transgressing the hexagram’s month"* refers to gathering the medicine only when the moon appears in *Zhen*, at the hour when the third day’s *geng* emerges. *"Zhun* employs *zi* and *shen"* denotes the locus where water is born and flourishes; *"Meng* employs *yin* and *xu"* denotes the position where fire is generated and stored. Each of the sixty hexagrams has its appointed day. Here, two hexagrams—*Zhun* and *Meng*—are briefly presented. *"Their full intricacies remain unexplored"* is the immortal elder’s humble admission of incomplete mastery, for the profound mysteries must be transmitted orally. Thus, the scripture says: *"These are not the common words of the world."* Only the perfected sages, who have attained immortality and penetrated the subtlest mysteries, can fully grasp their meaning. For those without the endowment of a perfected sage, how could they practice this Dao and become immortals?

*"Establishing righteousness and instituting punishments"* serves to prevent deceit; *"enacting benevolence and bestowing virtue"* serves to win hearts. *"Those who defy them meet misfortune; those who comply attain fortune"*—this means adhering to the law, clarifying decrees, acting with utmost sincerity, and proceeding with focused precision. *"Diligently observing the celestial stems and branches"* means that in a year, only one month is suitable; in a month, only one day; in a day, only one hour; in an hour, only one talisman is employed. *"Scrutinizing the waxing and waning"* requires discerning the water born of *dui*-metal, distinguishing its clarity and turbidity, and measuring its proportions. Even the slightest error—*"the tiniest irregularity"*—will invite blame and harm, sabotaging the elixir crucible.

Such distortions cause yin and yang to deviate; at the solstices, the celestial degrees shift. Midwinter becomes scorching heat, midsummer yields bitter frost. The equinoxes’ directions misalign, failing to correspond even by a moment’s measure. Drought and flood contend, wind and rain fall out of season; locusts surge like boiling water, and manifold anomalies emerge. Heaven displays its omens—mountains collapse, the earth splits. The filial son’s devotion moves the imperial pole.

chunks.original_text: 春秋二分以纵横，晨昏刻漏而不应，雨阳愆伏，怪异多端，如上咎征，皆喻临炉一差百错，总因炼已无功，致斯乖变。 愚者不责于己，反怨丹经。 若是大根，方寸真实，自悔自吝，诚心愈励，精勤不退，一念通天，自有仙助，临事必成。 亦犹孝子诚心，方能感动皇极。 心者神之舍，心实则神明自来。 言乃心之声，言孚则性情相感，语虽近出己口，声传远播他方。 败则招殃，成则致福。 事乖则或造兵革，事济则身乐太平。 成败乖济四者，皆由人心所为。 动静不妄，必依墨绳。 则四时应炁相求，刚柔和，五行正，大易之道，周流反复无不顺矣。 如上譬喻，要修丹者专心致志，虑其危殆而谨防之。 盖此丹道不特由我，亦由乎天； 天若或违，当以财宝精诚感之，不可有逆天道。 能顺天道，金丹成矣。 故同人先号咷而后笑。 《翼》曰：“君子之道，或出或处，或默或语。 二人同心，其利断金。 同心之言，其臭如兰。 ”同人之卦者，同心之人也。 其卦—阴而五阳，夫阴多阳少，则阳为主； 阳多阴少，则阴为主。 是以同人以孤阴而同乎老阳也。 故欲得乎同人之心，必以利而断之，方得同人之言也。 是以君子慎密委曲者，惟不妄言，而又托言语以为之阶，成丹之道之难，可不奉顺而谨之乎 晦朔合符章第十八 晦朔之间，合符行中。 混沌鸿蒙，牝牡相从。 滋液润泽，施化流通。 天地神明，不可度量。 利用安身，隐形而藏。 始于东北，箕斗之乡。 旋而右转，呕轮吐萌。 潜潭见象，发散精光。 昴毕之上，震为出征。 阳炁造端，初九潜龙。 阳以三立，阴以八通。 三日震动，八日兑行。 九二见龙，和平有明。 三五德就，乾体乃成。 九三夕惕，亏折神符。 盛衰渐革，终还其初。 巽继其统，固际操持。 九四或跃，进退道危。 艮主进止，不得逾时。 二十三日，典守弦期。 九五飞龙，天位加喜。 六五坤承，结括终始。 韫养众子，世为类母。 上九亢龙，战德于野，用九翩翩，为道规矩。 阳数已讫，讫则复起。 推情合性，转而相与。 循环璇玑，升降上下。 周流六爻，难可察睹。 故无常位，为易宗祖。 注云：此章象一月之晦，朔、弦、望，以比炼丹之行爻合符。 盖一年十二度，晦朔弦望，天上太阴有十二度，与太阳合壁，人间少阴有十二度，以隐行看经，此阴阳之正也。 惟少阴也，溟滓杳冥，“不可度量”，圣人测之，优游太极，方拟合符，始可行中，故号“先天”。 天上之太阴，每会太阳，日月合符，月在日之下，日在月之上，月上正日之精光，其光向天，非人可见。 亦犹男女交合，男在上，女在下，女为男覆而不可见。 当此晦朔，月在日之下，辉光未分，比人间之少阴也。 太极混沌之时，先天鸿蒙之内，经罢符至，初三庚方微阳将生，阳牡阴牝，相从配合，其中“滋液润泽”，自然“施化流通”，“天地神明，不可度量”也。 夫大道者，非圣贤之资则不能运行。 《翼》曰：“与天地合其德，与日月合其明，四时合其序，鬼神合其吉凶。 ”道性金丹之神妙，虽天地不能测度，虽神明不能猜量，何哉金丹乃先天之炁，圣人善与天地合德，逆施造化以生此炁也。 圣人能与日月合明，颠倒用功，以行此炁也。 圣人巧与四时合序，以用此炁，而寒暑不相拘。

At the spring and autumn equinoxes, the cardinal directions misalign; the clepsydra’s marks no longer correspond. Rain and sunshine falter, anomalies multiply—such portents of blame all illustrate how a single error at the crucible spawns a hundred faults, all stemming from the failure to refine the self. The foolish blame the alchemical scriptures instead of themselves. Yet if one’s root is deep and the square inch of the heart true, remorse and regret only steel the resolve. With unwavering diligence and a single thought piercing heaven, divine aid arrives, and success at the crucial moment is assured. Just as the filial son’s sincerity moves the imperial pole, so too does the heart house the spirit; when the heart is steadfast, the numinous naturally comes.

Speech is the voice of the heart; when words are trustworthy, nature and emotion resonate. Though words emerge from one’s own mouth, their sound carries far. Failure invites calamity, success brings blessing. When affairs go awry, strife may arise; when they prosper, one enjoys great peace. These four outcomes—success, failure, discord, and harmony—all arise from the human heart. In movement and stillness, one must adhere to the inked line. Then the four seasons respond to the qi’s summons, hardness and softness harmonize, the Five Phases align, and the Dao of the *Great Change* flows and cycles without obstruction.

The above analogies urge those cultivating the elixir to concentrate their minds, contemplate peril, and guard against it. For this elixir’s Way depends not only on oneself but also on heaven. If heaven resists, one must move it with treasures and sincerity, never opposing the heavenly Dao. By aligning with the heavenly Dao, the golden elixir is achieved. Thus, those of like mind first wail and later laugh.

The *Wings* states: “The noble one’s Way may emerge or withdraw, may speak or remain silent. When two hearts are as one, their sharpness cuts metal. Words of shared heart bear the fragrance of orchids.” The hexagram *Fellowship* represents those of one heart. Its line structure—one yin and five yang—shows that when yin is many and yang few, yang governs; when yang is many and yin few, yin governs. Thus, *Fellowship* unites a solitary yin with venerable yang. To win the heart of a fellow, one must sever with advantage, only then will their words align. Therefore, the noble one’s caution and tact lie in not speaking recklessly but using words as a bridge. The difficulty of the elixir’s Way—can one not revere and heed it?

**Chapter Eighteen: Conjoining the Talisman at Dark and New Moon**

Between dark and new moon, the talisman is conjoined and the center traversed. Primal chaos and vast obscurity—yin and yang follow one another. Nourishing fluids moisten and enrich, transformation flows unimpeded. Heaven and earth’s spirits defy measure; their use secures the body, concealing and storing form.

It begins in the northeast, the region of *Ji* and *Dou*. Turning rightward, the wheel spews forth sprouts. In the hidden depths, images appear, scattering radiant essence. Above *Mao* and *Bi*, *Zhen* sets forth on its campaign. Yang qi initiates; the first yang, the hidden dragon. Yang stands with three, yin flows with eight. On the third day, *Zhen* stirs; on the eighth, *Dui* moves. The second yang, the visible dragon, brings peace and clarity. When the virtues of three and five are complete, the *Qian* body is formed. The third yang, vigilant at dusk, chips away at the spirit-talisman. Flourishing and decline gradually transform, ultimately returning to the origin. *Xun* inherits the lineage, firmly grasping the boundary. The fourth yang may leap, advancing and retreating on a perilous path. *Gen* governs progress and pause, not overstepping its time. On the twenty-third day, one guards the crescent’s appointed hour. The fifth yang, the flying dragon, ascends to heaven’s position with joy. The sixth yin, *Kun* in submission, binds beginning and end. It nurtures the many offspring, becoming the mother of all kinds. The ninth yang, the exalted dragon, battles virtue in the wilds. With *yongjiu*, it flutters, becoming the Dao’s compass. The yang numbers conclude, then begin anew. Pushing sentiment to align with nature, they turn and unite. The jade armillary revolves, ascending and descending. The six lines circulate, difficult to perceive. Thus, there is no fixed position, for it is the ancestor of the *Changes*.

The commentary states: This chapter models the dark, new, crescent, and full moons to compare the elixir’s traversal of lines and conjoining of talismans. In a year’s twelve degrees, the dark, new, crescent, and full moons—heaven’s greater yin has twelve degrees, conjoining with the greater yang; the human realm’s lesser yin has twelve degrees, hiddenly following the scripture. This is the norm of yin and yang. Only the lesser yin, murky and obscure, “defies measure.” The sage gauges it, roaming the Supreme Ultimate, only then matching the talisman to traverse the center, hence called “prior heaven.”

Heaven’s greater yin meets the greater yang at each conjunction; sun and moon conjoin talismans. The moon lies below the sun, the sun above the moon. The moon receives the sun’s radiant essence, its light directed heavenward, unseen by humans. Just as in the union of man and woman—man above, woman below—the woman is covered by the man and unseen. At this dark and new moon, the moon lies below the sun, its brilliance undivided, like the human realm’s lesser yin.

In the Supreme Ultimate’s chaos, within the prior heaven’s vast obscurity, when the talisman’s term concludes, on the third day at *geng*, a faint yang is about to arise. Yang’s male and yin’s female follow and unite; within them, “nourishing fluids moisten and enrich,” naturally “transformation flows unimpeded.” “Heaven and earth’s spirits defy measure.”

The great Dao cannot be enacted without the resources of sages and worthies. The *Wings* states: “Harmonize virtue with heaven and earth, brightness with sun and moon, sequence with the four seasons, and fortune and misfortune with ghosts and spirits.” The wondrousness of the Dao-nature’s golden elixir—even heaven and earth cannot fathom it, even spirits cannot guess. How so? The golden elixir is the prior heaven’s qi. The sage excels at harmonizing virtue with heaven and earth, reversing creation’s workings to generate this qi. The sage matches brightness with sun and moon, inverting effort to circulate this qi. The sage skillfully aligns with the four seasons’ sequence, employing this qi so that cold and heat do not constrain one another.

chunks.original_text: 圣人潜与鬼神合吉凶，以成此炁，而鬼神见情状。 故“天地神明”，且“不可度量”，惟圣人为能也。 “利用安身，隐形而藏”，此何谓也坤道也。 坤之为用，坤宫有土，土制坎水，善利万物如不争者，水之用也，圣人能逆用之，乃得水之利。 《易》之“用六，利用永贞”者，坤之德也。 “始于东北，箕斗之乡”，何谓也每朔月与日会，必于箕斗之乡。 箕斗为艮，艮之为卦，阴侵阳也，号曰“鬼路”。 月每至此而失其明，故曰丧明。 有若世人顺行五行，生老病死，寒暑代谢也。 “施而右转”者，天道左运，日月星辰悉皆右转。 月至此乡，必晦而会，如璧如圭，一日二日，旋而右至于庚方，精光才吐，魄乃生焉。 毕月昴日，月借日光，光吐于下，如乾阳初生。 坤之下为震，象初三之夕，一阳二阴，乾之长男，得时行道，故“三日震动”也。 初八上弦，一阴二阳，坤之少女，兑受丁火，代坤行道，以主其事，阴阳和平，神明乃生，故曰“八日兑行”也。 三五为望，月全阳辉，故曰：“三五德就，乾体乃成。 ”如上爻符，比丹鼎中已得金水，太阴映日如生精魄，人身象月而生金丹，鼎中有丹，夕惕若厉，满则慎溢，盛则恐衰。 惟圣人为能慎终如始。 巽继其统，固济操持，徐运阴符，包裹阳炁。 艮主进止，符满下弦，渐结渐凝，天位加喜，抽添铅汞，铅尽汞干。 六五坤承，结括终始，铅汞俱化，金丹已成。 虽以一月喻其行持，功要十月，方拟成形，功满三年，功高则一纪，在人积行何如耳!若夫大圣人，再造阴阳，推情合性，转而相与，别立丹炉，复造九鼎大丹，亦如璇玑复建于子，比十二爻，周于一月，晦而至朔，朔则届爽，初阳再动于复卦矣。 故云“故无常位，为易之宗祖”也。 爻变功用章第十九 朔旦为复，阳炁始通。 出入无疾，立表微刚。 黄钟建子，兆乃滋彰。 播施柔暖，黎蒸得常。 临炉施条，开路正光。 光耀渐进，日以益长。 丑之大吕，结正低昂。 仰以成泰，刚柔并隆。 阴阳交接，小往大来。 辐辏于寅，运而趋时。 渐历大壮，侠列卯门。 榆荚堕落，还归本根。 刑德相负，昼夜始分。 夬阴以退，阳升而前。 洗濯羽翮，振索宿尘。 乾健盛明，广被四邻。 阳终于己，中而相干。 姤始纪序，履霜最先。 井底寒泉，午为蕤宾。 宾伏于阴，阴为主人。 遁世去位，收敛其精。 怀德俟时，栖迟昧冥。 否塞不通，萌者不生。 阴伸阳屈，没阳姓名。 观其权量，察众秋情。 任畜微稚，老枯复荣。 荠麦牙蘖，因冒以生。 剥烂肢体，消灭其形。 化炁既竭，亡失至神。 道穷则返，归乎坤元。 恒顺地理，承天布宣。 玄幽远眇，隔阂相连。 应度育种，阴阳之元。 廖廓恍惚，莫知其端。 先迷失轨，后为主君。 无平不陂，道之自然。 变易更盛，消息相因。 终坤复始，如循连环。 帝王承御，千载常存。 注云：上章言一月晦、朔、弦、望，采炼成丹之象，此章比一年十二月功行之象。 其初得丹，比为复卦，复者一阳伏五阴也。 圣贤攸行此道，则超凡人圣； 邪人若行此道，则失命而丧身。
chunks.translated_text:
The sage subtly harmonizes fortune and misfortune with ghosts and spirits, thereby completing this qi, and ghosts and spirits reveal their true forms. Thus, “heaven and earth’s spirits” are “beyond measure,” yet only the sage can achieve this.

“Employing it to secure the body, concealing form to hide”—what does this mean? It refers to the Way of Kun. In its function, Kun’s palace holds earth, and earth restrains Kan’s water. Its virtue benefits all things as if without contention—this is water’s function. The sage, by inverting its use, attains water’s benefit. The *Yijing*’s “use of six, employing it for eternal integrity” is Kun’s virtue.

“Beginning in the northeast, the region of Jidou”—what does this mean? Each new moon meets the sun in the Jidou region. Jidou corresponds to Gen, and Gen as a hexagram signifies yin encroaching upon yang, called the “ghostly path.” The moon, upon reaching this point, loses its brightness, hence called “losing its light.” This resembles the worldly cycle of the five phases—birth, aging, sickness, death—and the alternation of cold and heat.

“Applying and turning rightward”: heaven’s Dao moves left, while the sun, moon, and stars all turn right. When the moon reaches this region, it must darken to meet the sun, appearing like a jade disk or a gui tablet. On the first or second day, it turns rightward toward the geng direction, its radiant essence barely emerging, and its po begins to form. By the time of the full moon in Mao, the moon borrows the sun’s light, which shines from below, like the initial arising of qian’s yang. Kun’s lower position is Zhen, symbolizing the third evening—a single yang beneath two yins, qian’s eldest son, seizing the moment to enact the Dao, hence “on the third day, Zhen stirs.” On the eighth day, the first quarter appears—one yin beneath two yangs, kun’s youngest daughter, Dui, receiving ding fire, acting in kun’s stead to govern the affair. With yin and yang in harmony, spirit and brightness arise, hence “on the eighth day, Dui acts.”

At the fifteenth day, the full moon, the moon’s yang radiance is complete, thus: “At three and five, virtue is perfected, and the qian body is formed.” As the upper line corresponds, it resembles the elixir crucible where metal and water are obtained. The great yin reflects the sun, generating essence and po. The human body, mirroring the moon, produces the golden elixir. Within the crucible, the elixir forms; one remains vigilant as if facing peril, cautious when full lest it overflow, fearful when abundant lest it decline. Only the sage can remain as prudent at the end as at the beginning.

Xun continues the lineage, firmly securing and upholding it, gradually circulating the yin tally to envelop the yang qi. Gen governs advance and retreat; when the tally is full at the last quarter, it gradually congeals. Heaven’s position brings joy; lead and mercury are drawn and added, lead exhausted and mercury dried. At six-five, kun receives, binding the beginning and end. Lead and mercury both transform, and the golden elixir is complete. Though this analogy spans a single month’s practice, the work requires ten months to approximate completion, and three years to fulfill the merit. For the highest achievement, a full cycle of twelve years—it all depends on one’s accumulated conduct!

As for the great sage, who re-creates yin and yang, aligning emotion with nature, turning and uniting them, establishing a separate elixir furnace to forge the nine-cauldron great elixir—it is like the celestial pivot being re-established at zi, comparing the twelve lines to a month’s cycle, from darkness to new moon, and the new moon reaching dawn. The initial yang stirs again in the Fu hexagram. Thus it is said: “Having no fixed position, it is the ancestral origin of change.”

**Chapter Nineteen: The Function of Line Changes**

At the new moon’s dawn, Fu appears, and yang qi first flows.
Entering and exiting without hindrance, it establishes the subtle and firm.
Yellow Bell aligns with zi, and the omen flourishes.
Disseminating gentle warmth, the common people thrive in constancy.

At the crucible, the branch is applied, opening the path to true radiance.
The light gradually advances, the days lengthen.
Chou’s Great Lü binds, balancing high and low.
Lifting to form Tai, hardness and softness both flourish.

Yin and yang unite, the small departs and the great arrives.
Converging at yin, it moves and follows the season.
Gradually passing through Great Strength, it flanks the mao gate.
Elm pods fall, returning to their root.

Punishment and virtue contend, day and night first divide.
Guai’s yin retreats, yang ascends forward.
Washing and shaking feathers, it casts off old dust.
Qian’s vigor and brilliance broadly extend to the four neighbors.

Yang ends at si, centered and interacting.
Gou begins the sequence, treading frost first.
The cold spring at the well’s bottom—wu is Ruibin.
The guest submits to yin, yin becomes the host.

Withdrawing from the world and leaving position, it gathers its essence.
Cherishing virtue and awaiting the time, it dwells in obscurity.
Pi’s blockage is impassable; sprouts do not grow.
Yin extends, yang withdraws, and yang’s name is lost.

Observing its measure, examining the autumn’s multitude.
Nurturing the young and tender, the old and withered revive.
Shepherd’s purse and wheat sprout, growing beneath cover.
Bo’s decaying limbs dissolve, its form vanishes.

When the transforming qi is exhausted, the utmost spirit is lost.
When the Dao is exhausted, it returns to kun’s origin.
Eternally following earth’s principle, it receives heaven’s proclamation.
Mysterious, distant, and subtle, separated yet connected.

Responding to measure and nurturing life, it is yin and yang’s origin.
Vast and indistinct, none know its beginning.
First lost and astray, later becoming the lord.
No level without slope—this is the Dao’s nature.

Change and renewal grow ever more abundant, ebb and flow mutually dependent.
Kun ends and fu begins, like tracing a linked ring.
Emperors and kings receive and govern, enduring for a thousand generations.

The annotation states: The previous chapter described the waxing and waning of a month—new moon, full moon, quarters—and the imagery of refining the elixir. This chapter compares the work of the twelve months’ practice. The initial attainment of the elixir corresponds to the Fu hexagram, where one yang lies beneath five yins. If sages and worthies practice this Dao, they transcend the ordinary and enter sagehood; if the wicked practice it, they lose their lives and forfeit their bodies.

chunks.original_text: 文王故曰：“朋来无咎，返覆其道。 七日来复，利有攸往。 “朋来”者，有朋自远方来也； “无咎”者，有益而无损也； “返覆其道”者，用易之道也，颠倒而行也； “七日来复”者，月隐其光，七日再吐，亦犹人也经动七日而阳初生。 “利有攸往”者，善进而无失。 《东京赋》云：“日月会于龙[左犭右龙]者。 ”（[左犭右龙]音斗，尾星也。 ），谓阳将复。 孔子曰：“复其见天地之心乎”世人不知天地之心。 老子号此心为“玄牝之门”； 云房指此心为“生门死户”。 《易》曰“雷在地中复。 先王至日闭关，商旅不行，后不省方。 ”雷乃刚阳，地乃柔阴，以刚阳在柔阴之中，复彼先天之炁。 先王至此日行此道，则闭关而不省，方得专心致志。 “商旅”者，杂泛也； “不行”者，当绝其杂泛之事，专行其道。 故象传曰：“不远之复，以修身也。 ”又曰：“中行独复，以从道也。 “朔旦为复，阳炁始通”者，圣人之心一也。 “复”者，先伏而后能复也。 阳之始炁，出入相通，且无嫉害。 “立表微刚”者，乾动而直也。 黄钟之律，阳月建子。 “兆”者，众庶也，始也。 庶物生此阳炁，昔始滋彰； “播施柔暖，黎蒸得常”者，得复柔暖，一阳之炁，皆能复其常道也。 上阳子曰：“作丹之妙，其要在此，切毋轻忽也。 学道已得师诀，须晓三关三候，何也预营坛墠，先采药物。 既得药物，出入相通，行炼己功，柔暖播施，微温直透，此为初关第一候也。 临驭丹炉，施条接意，辟开道路，不僭不狂，分彩和光，愈低愈下。 大吕应丑，日景渐长，是为中关第二候也。 大簇律临，“仰以成泰”，泰之为卦，地上于天，阴若居上，水能润下，阳居于下，火临照上，故咸之。 《翼》曰：“柔上而刚下，二炁感应，以相与止而说。 男下女上，是以亨利贞。 ”夫五行颠倒，大地成宝。 柔施于前，饶他为主； 刚施于后，我反为宾。 牡初小往，牝乃大来； 金气相胥，阳全乾体。 此云刚柔并隆，阴阳交接，是为下关第三候也。 “渐历大壮”，结凝还丹； “侠列卯门”，榆荚归根；

King Wen of old declared: *"When companions arrive, there is no blame—reversing and returning to the Way. After seven days, the return comes; it is beneficial to proceed."* "Companions arrive" means companions come from afar; "no blame" means benefit without harm; "reversing and returning to the Way" refers to the practice of the *Yi*, acting in inversion. "After seven days, the return comes" speaks of the moon concealing its light, then re-emerging after seven days—just as humans, after seven days of movement, witness the first stirring of yang. "Beneficial to proceed" means advancing with goodness and no loss.

The *Eastern Capital Rhapsody* states: *"The sun and moon meet at the tail of the Dragon."* (The character *[左犭右龙]* is pronounced *dou*, referring to the tail star.) This signifies the imminent return of yang. Confucius said: *"In the return, do we not see the heart of Heaven and Earth?"* Yet the world does not know the heart of Heaven and Earth. Laozi named this heart the "Gate of the Mysterious Female"; Zhongli Quan pointed to it as the "Gate of Life and Door of Death."

The *Yi* says: *"Thunder lies within the earth—Fu. The former kings, on this day, closed the passes, and merchants and travelers did not move; the ruler did not attend to the four quarters."* Thunder is firm yang; earth is yielding yin. When firm yang resides within yielding yin, it restores the primordial qi. The former kings, on this day, practiced this Way, closing the passes and not attending to affairs, thereby focusing their minds and wills single-pointedly. "Merchants and travelers" represent miscellaneous distractions; "did not move" means cutting off such distractions to devote oneself wholly to the Way.

Thus, the *Xiang Zhuan* states: *"The return that is not distant is for cultivating the self."* It also says: *"The one who walks the middle path returns alone to follow the Way."* "At the dawn of the new moon, the return begins, and yang qi first flows"—the heart of the sage is one. "Return" means first concealing, then re-emerging. The initial qi of yang moves in and out, free from harm or envy.

"Erecting a marker of subtle firmness" refers to the movement and straightness of Qian. The pitch of Yellow Bell corresponds to the yang month of *zi*. "Omen" means the multitude, the beginning. All things are born from this yang qi, which first flourishes and becomes manifest. "Disseminating gentle warmth, the black-haired people attain constancy" means that through the return of gentle warmth, the qi of the first yang restores all to their proper Way.

Master Shangyang said: *"The subtlety of elixir-making lies precisely here—take heed not to treat it lightly. Those who study the Way, having received their teacher’s instructions, must understand the Three Passes and Three Signs. Why? To prepare the altar and first gather the medicinal substances. Once the substances are obtained, they move in and out, refining the work of the self, disseminating gentle warmth, allowing subtle warmth to penetrate directly—this is the First Pass and First Sign.*

*Guiding the elixir furnace, applying the firing times with intent, opening the path without excess or recklessness, distinguishing colors and harmonizing light, humbling oneself further—this is the Second Pass and Second Sign. When the pitch of Great Bamboo arrives, the sun’s shadow lengthens, corresponding to the month of *chou*. The hexagram *Tai* is formed, with earth above heaven. Though yin appears to be above, water naturally moistens downward; yang resides below, and fire rises to illuminate above—thus they unite.*

The *Wings* say: *"The yielding above and the firm below—these two qi interact and respond, coming together in stillness and joy. The male submits below, the female above—thus there is harmony and rightness."* When the Five Phases are inverted, the great earth becomes a treasure. Yielding is applied first, allowing the other to become the master; firmness is applied afterward, and I become the guest. The male begins with a small departure, while the female arrives in great measure. Metal and qi assist one another, and yang completes the body of Qian.

Here, firmness and yielding flourish together, yin and yang unite—this is the Third Pass and Third Sign. *"Gradually progressing to Great Strength,"* the elixir congeals and returns; *"flanking the gate of mao,"* the elm pods return to the root.

chunks.original_text: “刑德相负，昼夜始分”，言丹之兆，落在黄庭，以防以养，宜慎宜专。 夬之为卦，阴以决别，阳炁既回，金丹怀孕。 “乾健盛明”，金气已纯，阳终于巳。 运行阴符，姤承乍包，阳无走逸，阳复得阴，“阴为主人”。 坤之为化，初六履霜，井底寒泉，阴炁下来，六月为遁，敛精俟时。 否届七月，阴阳不通，阴伸阳屈，阳炁内明。 八月观象，量察秋情，任畜微稚，若麦之蘖； 老枯复荣，若齑之芽。 化气既竭，剥消其形，道穷则返，归乎坤元。 一来一往，恒顺承天。 此书撰作，深有法度。 或序冒头，或括结尾。 无冒头者，结尾括之； 无结尾者，冒头总之。 即如此章，是无冒头而以结尾括之。 其首句曰：“朔旦为复”，复而临，临而泰，泰而大壮，大壮而夬，夬而乾，乾而姤，姤而遁，遁而否，否而观，观而剥，剥而坤。 尾却结曰：“元幽远眇，隔阂相连”。 只此两语，最为简易。 “元幽远眇”者，阴阳二物，至玄极幽，不可捉摸； 至玄极眇，不可思议，而其造化，功倍天地。 “隔阂相连”者，二物间隔，动几万里，若得黄婆以媒合之，则虽至远而至近也。 是以两物应度而育种，为“阴阳之元”。 圣人用之而行其道，“廖廓恍惚”而不可捉摸者，未容度量，圣人推之以逆其用也。 “先迷失轨，后为主君”者，柔顺利贞，君子攸行，先迷失道，后顺得常，此《十翼》之辞也。 仙翁引而详之，中言“阴为主人”，末曰“后为主君”，皆坤之利，地之道也。 “无平不陂，道之自然”。 水之至平，潴为渊陂； 畔岸不流，陂若盈科，则水自泛。 以水喻道，自然之理。 “变易更盛”，犹复至乾； “消息相因”，如姤至坤。 故云：“终坤复始，如循连环”也。 “帝王承御，千载常存”者，若帝王能承御乾坤逆顺之道，则千载之寿，亦未为多； 若功崇行着，白日升天，亦分内事。 昔黄帝一世为民，修世间福，再世乃得为臣，复修出世功德，三世乃得为君。 遂捐天下，离弃万机，寻山水幽绝处，得鼎湖之君山，炼此九还大丹； 丹成之后，白日乘龙而上升也。 即洞庭湖，湖中有山，因黄帝炼丹，号日君山也。 养性立命章第二十 将欲养性，延命却期。
chunks.translated_text:
“Punishment and virtue bear one another, day and night first divide”—this speaks of the omen of the elixir, descending into the Yellow Court, where it must be guarded and nurtured with care and focus.

In the *Guai* hexagram, yin severs and parts, while yang qi returns, and the golden elixir conceives. *“Qian’s vigor shines brightly”*—metal qi is now pure, and yang ends at *si*. Moving the yin tally, *Gou* suddenly embraces, preventing yang’s escape; yang regains yin, and *“yin becomes the master.”*

In *Kun*’s transformation, the first six treads frost—cold springs lie at the well’s bottom, yin qi descends, and the sixth month brings retreat. Essence is gathered, awaiting the hour. By the seventh month of *Pi*, yin and yang do not communicate; yin extends while yang withdraws, and yang qi shines within. In the eighth month of *Guan*, one observes the signs, measuring autumn’s mood, nurturing the tender and young, like wheat’s sprouts; the withered revives, like mustard’s shoots. When the transforming qi is exhausted, its form is worn away by *Bo*. When the Way is exhausted, it returns—reverting to *Kun*’s origin. Coming and going, it eternally follows and accords with Heaven.

This text’s composition holds deep method and order: some chapters begin with an overture, others conclude with a summary. Where there is no overture, the summary binds it; where there is no summary, the overture unifies it. This chapter, for instance, lacks an overture and is bound by its conclusion. Its opening line reads: *“At the new moon’s dawn, it is *Fu*; *Fu* becomes *Lin*, *Lin* becomes *Tai*, *Tai* becomes *Dazhuang*, *Dazhuang* becomes *Guai*, *Guai* becomes *Qian*, *Qian* becomes *Gou*, *Gou* becomes *Dun*, *Dun* becomes *Pi*, *Pi* becomes *Guan*, *Guan* becomes *Bo*, *Bo* becomes *Kun*.”* The closing lines summarize: *“Primal, profound, distant, subtle—barriers yet linked.”* These two phrases are most concise.

*“Primal, profound, distant, subtle”*—yin and yang, two substances, reach the utmost mystery and obscurity, beyond grasp or fathoming; they attain the utmost subtlety, beyond thought or conjecture, yet their transformation’s power surpasses Heaven and Earth. *“Barriers yet linked”*—though the two are separated by vast distances, if the Yellow Dame mediates their union, the farthest becomes the nearest. Thus, the two substances align with measure and conceive the seed—this is *“the origin of yin and yang.”* The sage employs them to enact the Dao, and what is *“boundless and indistinct”*—beyond measure—the sage reverses to apply.

*“First lost, then misguided; later, the lord and ruler”*—yielding, smooth, beneficial, and upright, the noble one’s path: first straying from the Way, later following the constant. These are the words of the *Ten Wings*. The immortal elder elaborates: in the midst, *“yin becomes the master”*; at the end, *“later, the lord and ruler”*—all are *Kun*’s advantage, Earth’s Dao.

*“No plain without slope—this is the Dao’s nature.”* Water’s utmost level pools into a deep abyss; when banks block its flow, the slope fills like a basin, and water naturally overflows. This analogy illustrates the Dao’s natural principle.

*“Transforming and ever-increasing”*—like *Fu* ascending to *Qian*; *“waning and waxing in turn”*—like *Gou* descending to *Kun*. Thus it is said: *“Ending with *Kun*, beginning anew, like tracing a linked ring.”*

*“If emperors and kings uphold and serve the Dao of Qian and Kun’s reversal and compliance, their lives span a thousand years, which is not excessive. If their merit is lofty and conduct illustrious, ascending to Heaven in broad daylight is but their due.”* In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor first lived as a commoner, cultivating worldly blessings; in his second life, he became a minister, then cultivated transcendent merits; in his third, he became a ruler. He then relinquished the world, abandoning myriad affairs, seeking secluded mountains and waters. At Junshan by Lake Dongting, he found the Dinghu cauldron and refined the Great Elixir of Nine Returns. After its completion, he ascended in broad daylight, riding a dragon. This is why the mountain in Dongting Lake is called Junshan.

**Chapter Twenty: Nurturing Nature and Establishing Destiny**—To nurture nature, prolong life, and reverse fate’s decree.

chunks.original_text: 审思后末，当虑其先。 人所秉躯，体本一无。 元精云布，因炁托初。 阴阳为度，魂魄所居。 阳神日魂，阴神月魄。 魂之与魄，互为室宅。 性主处内，立置鄞鄂。 情主营外，筑垣城廓。 城廓完全，人物乃安。 爰斯之时，情合乾坤。 乾动而直，炁布精流； 坤静而翕，为道舍庐。 刚施而退，柔化以滋。 九还七返，八归六居。 男白女赤，金火相拘。 则水定火，五行之初。 上善若水，清而无瑕。 道之形象，真一难图。 变而分布，各自独居。 类如鸡子，白黑相符，纵广一寸，以为始初。 四肢五脏，筋骨乃俱。 弥历十月，脱出其胞。 骨弱可卷，肉滑若铅。 注云：此章言人先须养性，乃可修命。 且性者何也乾之物也，人能养之，则乾阳不亏； 精从内守，炁自外生，可以炼丹，可以入圣。 世人莫知性命两者为何（一为一）物，或猜性是灵明知觉，或以性为肉团顽心，或认思想识神为性，或指不可捉摸为性，或拟顽空为性； 或以令为命，他岂知杳杳冥冥之物为性（一为命），又焉知生生化化之门为命。 惟只盲猜梦想，怎达圣人之道哉黄帝曰：天性，人也，人心，机也。 君子得之固穷（一为躬），小人得之轻命。 孔子曰：“穷理尽性以至于命。 ”孟子曰：“存其心，养其性，所以俟天命也，夭寿不贰，修身以俟之，所以立命也。 ”圣人之道，传至孟子，忒杀分明。 《翼》曰“昔者圣人作《易》也，将以顺性命之理，是以立天之道，曰阴与阳； 立地之道，曰柔与刚； 立人之道，曰仁与义。 ”上仙云：“修性不修命，如何能入圣； 修命先修性，方入修行径。 ”人言释氏修性，道家修命，天下岂有二道哉是不参孟子存心养性，修身立命之道。 盖欲立命，先养其性； 若不悟性，焉能知命故《中庸》“天命之谓性，率性之谓道。 ”是以圣人无两心也。 此谓将欲养性，延命却期。 世人不知何者为养性，洞宾乃以炼丹以晓之； 不知何者为立命，张许乃以炼丹喻之。 惟精惟一，允执厥中，此养性也； 男女媾精，万物化生，此立命也。 积精累气，此养性也； 流戊就己，此立命也。 “审思后末”者，人负聪慧，执僻不回，谓有生必有死，奚有长生也哉!圣仙与佛，皆天所生，师岂能授，人岂能为！ 是不审思，甘分守死。 “当虑其先”者，“虑”即念也。 当念我身从何而有，若云父母阴阳之炁所生，则阴阳之炁，必可延命，必可成仙佛矣。 故修大丹，与生身受炁之初，浑无差别，但有逆顺耳!仲尼曰：“未知生，焉知死”圣人明性命之所以死生，示阴阳之道，缘何逆顺。 故顺而生物者，人也； 逆而生丹者，圣也。 此之谓“元精云布，因气托初”。 何谓“阴阳为度，魂魄所居”盖阴阳以魂魄为体，魂魄就阴阳为舍。 离为日魂，坎为月魄； 魄乃阴中之阳，戊土专之； 魂乃阳中之阴，己土直之； 魂魄互为室宅，阴阳两相交通。 性主实精于内，立置鄞鄂； 情主伏炁于外，筑垣城廓。 “城”者何也承华之包也。 “廓”者何也炼丹之室也。 当斯之时，乾之性动而直，则精炁合体； 坤之情静而翕，“为道舍庐”。 刚而直者，一施则退； 柔而化者，布润以滋。 丹产于鼎，还返成功。 所谓“九还”者地四生金，天九成银，龙虎相交，金银之炁，复还鼎中，故云“九还”。

Examine the end with care, and first consider its beginning. The body that humans receive is fundamentally rooted in nothingness. Primordial essence spreads like clouds, borne by qi at the outset. Yin and yang serve as its measure, the dwelling of hun and po. The yang spirit is the sun’s hun; the yin spirit, the moon’s po. Hun and po, each becomes the other’s chamber. Nature presides within, establishing its inner bounds; emotion governs without, building walls and outer enclosures. When walls and enclosures are complete, beings find peace. At this time, emotion harmonizes with Heaven and Earth. Heaven moves and straightens, qi spreads and essence flows; Earth is still and receptive, serving as the Dao’s abode. The firm extends then retreats; the yielding transforms and nourishes. Nine returns, seven reversals, eight reunions, six residences. The male is white, the female red—metal and fire restrain each other. Then water settles fire, the inception of the Five Phases. Supreme goodness resembles water, clear and without flaw. The Dao’s form and image, the True One, are difficult to depict. Though transformed and dispersed, each abides alone. Like a chicken’s egg, white and black align, its length and breadth a single inch, the beginning of all. Four limbs and five viscera, sinews and bones all complete. After ten months, it emerges from its womb. Bones soft and pliable, flesh smooth as lead.

*This chapter speaks of how one must first nurture nature before cultivating destiny. What, then, is nature? It is the substance of Qian. If one can nurture it, then Qian’s yang will not wane. Essence is guarded within, qi arises without—this is how one refines the elixir and enters sagehood. Yet people do not know what these two, nature and destiny, truly are. Some guess nature to be luminous awareness, others take it as the stubborn heart of flesh, or identify thought and perception as nature, or point to the intangible as nature, or liken it to empty nothingness. Some take orders as destiny, yet how would they know that the profound and obscure is nature (or destiny), or recognize the gate of ceaseless transformation as destiny? Merely blindly guessing and dreaming—how can one grasp the Dao of the sages?*

The Yellow Emperor said: “Heavenly nature is human; the human heart is a mechanism. The noble one, gaining it, remains steadfast in adversity (or in person); the petty one, gaining it, treats life lightly.” Confucius said: “Exhaust principle, fulfill nature, and so reach destiny.” Mencius said: “Preserve the heart, nurture nature—this is how one awaits Heaven’s mandate. Whether short-lived or long-lived, remain unwavering; cultivate the self to await it—this is how one establishes destiny.” The Dao of the sages, transmitted to Mencius, is exceedingly clear. The *Wings* states: “Of old, the sages composed the *Yi* to accord with the principles of nature and destiny. Thus they established Heaven’s Dao as yin and yang, Earth’s Dao as yielding and firm, and humanity’s Dao as benevolence and righteousness.”

The perfected immortals say: “To cultivate nature without cultivating destiny—how can one enter sagehood? Cultivate destiny only after cultivating nature, then one enters the path of practice.” Some say Buddhists cultivate nature while Daoists cultivate destiny—how could there be two Daos in the world? This is not to fathom Mencius’ way of preserving the heart, nurturing nature, cultivating the self, and establishing destiny. Thus, to establish destiny, first nurture nature. Without awakening to nature, how can one know destiny? Therefore, the *Doctrine of the Mean* says: “What Heaven decrees is called nature; following nature is called the Dao.” Thus, the sage has no dual heart.

This is what is meant by “to nurture nature, prolong life, and reverse fate’s decree.” People do not know what nurturing nature entails, so Lü Dongbin uses elixir refinement to illustrate it. They do not know what establishing destiny entails, so Zhang and Xu use elixir refinement as a metaphor. “Only essence, only unity, holding fast to the center”—this is nurturing nature. “Male and female unite essence, the myriad things transform and arise”—this is establishing destiny. “Accumulating essence, amassing qi”—this is nurturing nature. “Flowing wu to ji”—this is establishing destiny.

“Examine the end with care” refers to those who, though endowed with intelligence, cling to bias and refuse to turn back, asserting that where there is birth, there must be death—how could there be longevity? Sages, immortals, and buddhas are all born of Heaven; how could a teacher confer them, or a person create them? Failing to examine this, one resigns to death. “First consider its beginning” means “consider” is to reflect. One should reflect: from whence does my body arise? If one says it comes from the qi of parents’ yin and yang, then that qi of yin and yang must be able to prolong life and attain sagehood or buddhahood. Thus, refining the Great Elixir is no different from the moment of receiving qi at birth—only the direction differs.

Confucius said: “Not knowing life, how can one know death?” The sage clarifies the causes of life and death in nature and destiny, demonstrating the Dao of yin and yang and the reasons for their reversal. Thus, following the flow to give life to beings is the human way; reversing the flow to give birth to the elixir is the sagely way. This is what is meant by “primordial essence spreads like clouds, borne by qi at the outset.”

What does “yin and yang serve as its measure, the dwelling of hun and po” mean? Yin and yang take hun and po as their substance, while hun and po take yin and yang as their abode. Li is the sun’s hun; Kan is the moon’s po. Po is yang within yin, governed by wu earth; hun is yin within yang, governed by ji earth. Hun and po become each other’s chambers, yin and yang mutually communicating. Nature presides over true essence within, establishing its inner bounds; emotion governs qi without, building walls and outer enclosures.

What is the “wall”? It is the encasing of the radiant flower. What is the “enclosure”? It is the chamber for refining the elixir. At this time, Qian’s nature moves and straightens, so essence and qi unite; Kun’s emotion is still and receptive, serving as the Dao’s abode. The firm and straight, once extended, retreats; the yielding and transformative, spreading moisture, nourishes. The elixir is born in the crucible, returning and reversing to completion.

What is meant by “nine returns”? Earth produces metal in four phases; Heaven completes silver in nine. Dragon and tiger intertwine, the qi of metal and silver returns to the crucible—hence “nine returns.”

chunks.original_text: 其“七返”者，地二生火，天七成砂，魂魄相恋，砂火之精，返照鼎中，故云“七返”。 “八归”者，天三生木，地八成汞，戊己一合，木汞之真，归炼鼎中，故云“八归”。 曰“六居”者，天一生水，地六成铅，性情相感，铅汞之妙，回居鼎中，故云“六居”。 “男白女赤，金水相拘”，男属青龙之木，女属白虎之金，被离火之精，炼而还赤也。 “则水定火”者，坛墠精严，药物真正，须则其水之多少而抽添之，约其火之老嫩而烹炼之，此时为五行造化之初。 “上善若水”者，水中有金，能生丽水，探其至清，全无挠动，无质无瑕，方能变化，是云“上善”。 “道之形象”者，男女即道之形，乾坤乃道之象； 形与象之中，能生真一之炁，乃不可以尽其形而图其象也。 故此形此象，各任化机，分布而居，秉生秉杀，甲乙自东而游； 庚辛自西而舍，故云“各自独居”也。 “类如鸡子”者，还丹有形也； “白黑相符”者，阴阳得匹也；

The "seven returns" refer to Earth’s second phase producing fire and Heaven’s seventh phase completing cinnabar. As hun and po yearn for each other, the essence of cinnabar and fire reflects back into the crucible—hence "seven returns."

The "eightfold return" speaks of Heaven’s third phase producing wood and Earth’s eighth phase completing mercury. When wu and ji unite, the true essence of wood and mercury returns to refine within the crucible—hence "eightfold return."

The "sixfold dwelling" denotes Heaven’s first phase producing water and Earth’s sixth phase completing lead. As nature and emotion resonate, the marvel of lead and mercury revolves and resides within the crucible—hence "sixfold dwelling."

"Male white, female red—metal and water constrain each other": the male belongs to the Azure Dragon’s wood, the female to the White Tiger’s metal. Refined by the essence of Li fire, they revert to red.

"Thus water stabilizes fire": when the altar is pure and the medicinal substances authentic, one must adjust the water’s quantity by adding or withdrawing, and regulate the fire’s intensity by refining. This marks the inception of the Five Phases’ transformation.

"Supreme goodness resembles water": within water lies metal, capable of generating flowing water. When its utmost clarity is attained, utterly undisturbed, without substance or flaw, only then can transformation occur—this is called "supreme goodness."

"The Dao’s form and image": male and female embody the Dao’s form, Qian and Kun manifest its image. Within form and image, the true unity of qi arises—yet one cannot exhaust its form nor depict its image. Thus, this form and this image each follow their transformative mechanisms, dispersing to reside in their places, wielding life and death. Jia and Yi roam from the East; Geng and Xin lodge in the West—hence "each dwells alone."

"Like a hen’s egg": the returned elixir possesses form. "Black and white align": yin and yang achieve union.

chunks.original_text: 方诸非星月，安能得水浆？ 二炁玄且远，感化尚相通，何况近存身？ 切在于心胸。 阴阳配日月，水火为效征。 注云：阳燧者，阳之物也，其中有炁，故感日而能生火。 方诸者，阴之物也，其中有精，故感月而能生水。 日月有天之高远，阳燧方诸之至微，阴阳二炁，尚相感化。 况乎人身，真阴真阳，切在心胸，可亲可密，近而易求，安有相通而不感化哉缘以后之人不得其道耳!人身之阴阳，以比天上之日月； 诸燧之水火，以喻人身之精炁。 无情之物，尚尔相通； 有情有灵，自然交感。 且天地间最灵者人也。 虽至贱至愚者，皆知阴阳化育之理，不待教令而使之然。 一切愚迷，但知顺行以生人物，至于逆用，非师罔通。 盖逆用阴阳之道，乃炼精伏炁以成丹也。 此章单明阴阳二炁以相通感而成造化也。 关键三宝章第二十二 耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中，旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同，为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷。 离炁内营卫，坎乃不用聪，兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙，三者既关键，缓体处空房。 委志归虚无，无念以为常。 证难以推移，心专不纵横，寝寐神相抱，觉悟候存亡。 颜色浸以润，骨节益坚强。 排却众阴邪，然后立正阳。 修之不辍休，庶炁云雨行。 淫淫若春泽，液液象解冰，从头流达足，究竟复上升，往来洞无极，怫怫被容中。 反者道之验，弱者德之柄。 耕耘宿污秽，细微得调畅。 浊者清之路，昏久则昭明。 注云：此章详明炼丹入室之密旨。 学者得师口诀，便须诵此章万遍，句句熟玩，字字寻详，勿轻易读过去，一字不逗，不能成丹。 盖此章乃《参同契》着紧合尖处。 其中有不以语言泄露者，上天所宝也。 且夫人生于世，性无有不善。
chunks.translated_text:
Just as the yang-burning mirror cannot produce fire without the sun,
So too the *fangzhu* cannot yield water or broth without the stars and moon.
The two qi are dark and distant,
Yet their resonance and transformation still interflow—
How much more so within the nearness of this embodied self?
All lies intimately within the heart and breast.

Yin and yang pair with the sun and moon;
Water and fire serve as their manifest signs.
[Annotation:] The *yang-sui* is a yang object, containing within it qi, and thus responds to the sun to generate fire. The *fangzhu* is a yin object, containing within it essence, and thus responds to the moon to generate water. Though the sun and moon are lofty and remote in the heavens, and the *yang-sui* and *fangzhu* are of the utmost subtlety, the two qi of yin and yang still mutually resonate and transform. How much more so within the human body, where true yin and true yang lie intimately within the heart and breast, so close and easily sought—how could they fail to interflow and transform? It is only because later people have lost the Way!

The yin and yang of the human body may be likened to the sun and moon in the heavens;
The water and fire of the various burning mirrors serve as metaphors for the essence and qi of the human body.
Even inanimate things thus interflow—
How much more do sentient, spiritual beings naturally interact and resonate?
Among all things between heaven and earth, humans are the most spiritually endowed.
Even the basest and most ignorant know the principle of yin and yang’s transformative nurturance,
And do not require instruction to act accordingly.
Yet all the ignorant and deluded know only the sequential course that gives birth to beings—
As for the reverse application, without a teacher, none can fathom it.
For the reverse application of yin and yang is the Way of refining essence and subduing qi to form the elixir.

This chapter simply clarifies how the two qi of yin and yang interflow and resonate to accomplish transformation.

**Chapter Twenty-Two: The Three Treasures as the Pivotal Mechanism**

The three treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—
Seal them tightly, let nothing pass through.
The true person withdraws into the deep abyss,
Floating and wandering, guarding the compass’s center.
Turning and curving to see and hear,
Opening and closing all in unison—
These serve as the pivot and axle for the self,
In movement and stillness, inexhaustibly.

The *li* qi inwardly defends and protects;
The *kan* then does not employ hearing.
The *dui* closes, not speaking—
Rare words accord with the primal chaos.
Once these three are secured as the pivotal mechanism,
Relax the body and dwell in the empty chamber.
Entrust the will to return to emptiness and nonbeing,
Taking absence of thought as the constant norm.

Proof is difficult to shift;
The heart must focus, not straying east or west.
In sleep, spirit embraces spirit;
In waking, await the moment of presence or absence.
The complexion gradually becomes moist and lustrous,
The bones and joints grow ever more firm and strong.
Expel all the yin demons,
Then establish the true yang.

Unceasing in cultivation,
The qi will then move like clouds and rain.
Drizzling like spring’s gentle rain,
Flowing like melting ice—
From the head it streams down to the feet,
Then ultimately ascends again.
Coming and going, penetrating the boundless,
Permeating the body’s every vessel.

Reversal is the verification of the Dao;
Weakness is the handle of virtue.
Plowing and weeding the long-accumulated filth,
The finest subtleties attain harmony and smoothness.
The turbid is the path to clarity;
Prolonged darkness will then shine bright.

[Annotation:] This chapter expounds in detail the secret essentials of entering the chamber to refine the elixir. Once the student receives the teacher’s oral instructions, they must recite this chapter ten thousand times, pondering each line and scrutinizing each character. Do not read carelessly past it—even a single word misplaced will prevent the elixir’s formation. For this chapter is the most crucial and precise point of the *Cantong Qi*. Within it are matters not to be divulged in words—treasured by heaven above.

Moreover, of all born into this world,
There is none whose nature is not originally good.

chunks.original_text: 及乎年既长，非负上圣之资，介然自守者，鲜不淫朋妄友，牵诱于外，声色嗜欲，迷惑于内，六根门头，色色皆爱； 日用夜作，件件戕贼。 最苦毒者，耳、目、口也。 耳听乎声，目视乎色，口嗜乎味。 由此之故，福从色败，害随声至，病因口入，梦生醉死，递递何穷。 学士多不能成道者，皆被耳、目、口三者，邻朋互诱，汨丧其真。 仙翁以耳、目、口为三宝者，尊重而不敢轻放，是用闭塞勿令发通。 入室之际，大用现前，六根大定，方可采炼。 “真人”即己土也； “潜深渊”者，用己土去克水以求丹。 “浮游守规中”者，“规中”名“造化窟”也，若炼大丹于此一符之顷，切须慎密。 “浮游”者，常静而又常应，暂时不离此； 用“守”者勤勤内照，诚有所待也。 此两句又为《参同契》中合尖处，用一下大斧底工夫相似。 是以真仙圣师所出玄言法语，万世莫能猜之。 上阳子因尽泄之者，但愿人人皆明此道而行之也。
chunks.translated_text:
As years grow long, those not endowed with sagely capacity—those who do not steadfastly guard their integrity—rarely avoid being led astray by reckless companions and deceitful friends, drawn outward by their influence, while within, sounds and sights, cravings and desires bewilder the mind. At the gates of the six senses, every perception becomes an object of attachment; day in and day out, each moment wears away the essence. The most bitter poisons are the ear, the eye, and the mouth. The ear listens to sounds, the eye gazes upon forms, the mouth craves flavors. Thus, fortune is ruined by form, harm arrives with sound, illness enters through the mouth, dreams arise and death comes in drunkenness—an endless cycle of suffering. Most scholars fail to attain the Dao because these three—ear, eye, and mouth—along with neighboring temptations and mutual enticements, drown their true nature.

The Immortal Elder regards the ear, eye, and mouth as the "Three Treasures," honoring them and never daring to indulge them lightly. Thus, he seals them tightly to prevent their opening. Only when entering the chamber, with the great function manifest before one, and the six senses in profound stillness, may the work of gathering and refining begin.

The "True Person" is one’s own earth; "lurking in the deep abyss" means using one’s earth to overcome water in the quest for the elixir. "Floating and roaming, guarding the center of the compass" refers to the "Cavern of Creation"—if refining the great elixir in the span of this single token, one must be vigilant and discreet. "Floating and roaming" means abiding in constant stillness while ever responsive, never straying for even a moment; "guarding" means diligently turning the light inward, earnestly awaiting the moment. These two lines are another crucial and precise point in the *Cantong Qi*, akin to wielding a great axe with utmost effort.

Thus, the profound words and teachings uttered by true immortals and sagely masters remain beyond the guesswork of ten thousand generations. Master Shangyang revealed them fully, wishing only that all might understand and practice this Way.
