For the supreme Dao is treasured by Heaven; those of superior roots and wisdom practice tirelessly, refining both nature and life, uniting form and spirit in wondrous harmony, merging with the Dao in truth, their virtue deep and merit high. Thus they are lauded in such terms, paying homage to the Immortal Lords and being named Perfected Ones. Every person may undertake this great merit, achieve this great freedom—do not abandon yourself because the task seems difficult, nor neglect cultivation because your conditions seem meager. Laozi, Zhang, and Ge were but men, not fallen from the heavens; Śākyamuni and Bodhidharma were but men, not risen from the earth. With steadfast heart and courage, all things become easily accomplished. Practitioners of resolve, reflect deeply and strive with effort.

**Chapter Thirty-Four: Mending Omissions and Filling Gaps**

The *Cantong Qi* presents an outline, yet it is not entirely unified, its discourse overflowing, its subtleties not fully expounded, its omissions and approximations left wanting. Now I have compiled and recorded this to mend its gaps, refine its obscurities, link its threads in succession, align its purport, and ensure its course remains unerring. Thus I have composed this, designating three corresponding categories, so that the essence and nature of the *Great Change* may be fully revealed.

*Yi* "floating right," *Ding* "civil fire," *Ji* "essence-metal," *Xin* "generation-silver," *Gui* "true lead"—five phases in harmonious accord.
Three woods, two fires, five earths, four metals, one water.
*Jia* "sinking left," *Bing* "martial fire," *Wu* "medicine," *Geng* "generation-gold," *Ren* "true mercury"—each has its proper union.

The nature and essence of the *Great Change* each conform to their measure. The teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, when examined, may be applied. The work of furnace and fire has its true basis. The three Ways emerge from one, all following the same path. Branches, stems, flowers, and leaves bear fruit in abundance, yet the root remains the source, never losing its original purity. What is spoken here is sincere, carefully considered, and without error.

Like the midwinter season, when bamboo and trees are all broken and harmed,
Assisting yang, the merchant travels are questioned; the lord deeply conceals himself.
Align with the seasons, follow the celestial rhythms, seal your mouth and speak not.

The Dao of Heaven is vast and boundless, the Great Mystery formless,
Empty and still, unseen, its vastness dissolving into nothingness.
Errors and mistakes lose the thread of affairs; words return to harm oneself.

Distinguish and arrange these four images to enlighten later generations, who are blind to them.

This scripture holds the power of great liberation and great spiritual penetration. If one hears this scripture, serpents and tigers cannot harm them; if one recites this scripture, plagues and dysentery dare not arise; if one comprehends this scripture, hell cannot seize or restrain them; if one practices this scripture, heaven’s halls bring natural joy. Wherever this scripture resides, golden light constantly crisscrosses the void, and empty space births whiteness. Should one witness this, their lifespan extends by six times six. Those who make offerings and faithfully receive it gain boundless merit—how much more so for those who steadfastly cultivate and diligently practice it?

**Chapter Thirty-Five: Self-Narrative to Introduce Later Sections**

A rustic from the outskirts of Kuaiji, a withered scholar from a secluded valley, I cling to simplicity and plainness, taking no delight in power or glory. Dwelling in obscurity and neglecting profit and fame, I hold fast to tranquility and seek peace in my time. Living in quietude, I have composed this text.

I sing of the *Great Change*, the legacy of the Three Sages, examining its purport to find a unified discourse. My aim is to align with principle and radiate the spirit. Through spiritual transformation and free circulation, the four seas attain peace. I set it forth as a calendar for all ages to follow, a guide for governance that is not cumbersome. It draws inward to nurture nature, embracing the naturalness of the Yellow and the Old. In the depth of one’s virtue, one returns to the root and reverts to the origin. It is near in my heart, not apart from my own body. Embracing the One without abandonment, one may endure forever. Paired with refined ingestion, the male and female are arrayed. Cast aside the cinnabar of Wudu and discard the eight minerals. Discerning their use, one completes things—what the world treasures. Three strands are arranged, their branches and stems interconnected. Though they emerge differently and bear different names, all stem from a single gate. This is not mere accumulation of phrases or harmonious parallelism; it contains truth, and its coarse elements may yet be observed. If I were to embellish falsehoods, I would only incur superfluous faults.

I entitle it *The Kinship of the Three*, glimpsing but its beginning. Its words are few, yet its meaning vast—later generations should revere it. Abandoning the times to avoid harm, I take refuge in the hills and mountains. Roaming the vast expanse, I dwell beside ghosts. Transforming my form into an immortal, I sink into silence and stillness. A hundred generations hence, I wander among humans, spreading my feathered wings to the east, west, south, and north.

When Tang faced dire straits, drought and flood divided the wells. The leaves of the boughs withered and yellowed, losing their flourishing splendor. The virtuous bear one another’s burdens—peace and stability enable long life.

The great Dao is difficult to fathom; can the returning elixir change or shift? Fire arrays metal as its body, earth restrains water to form a circle. In the initial refinement, sixteen ounces are swallowed, ingesting the waxing and waning moon. Constantly paired with refined ingestion, one returns to the root and reverts to the origin. Plants and trees are not of the same kind—metals and stones are all discarded. Discerning their use, one peers into creation; the world treasures this lead. Through purity, one attains true cultivation; through diligence, one seeks the natural. The Supreme Sage treasures the *Golden Scripture*, accumulating merit and forming karmic bonds. Qi refines the Primordial Origin; the Most High commands the extension of essence. The blade is sharp, towering and lofty; Yu Di grasps the Supreme Mystery. The *Mud Pill* radiates divine brilliance, resplendent and soaring eightfold. The Great Canopy aligns with the Jade Capital; the cinnabar phoenix dances in flight. The *Cave Chapters* shake the Nine Capitals; ghosts and demons all confess their transgressions. Waving the branch, the sweet dew nectar flows; unfolding the discourse, one listens to the true explanation. Golden youths scatter celestial flowers; jade maidens hold jasper feasts. The divine wind resounds in the layered heavens; the *Brahma*-qi fills the field of mushrooms.
